entry.title: Welcome to Cryptography & Complexity
entry.content:
Welcome to my blog! I’m Chethana R V, a PhD researcher at Dayananda Sagar University, Bengaluru, specializing in Quantum Cryptography and Post-Quantum Cryptography.

What to Expect

This blog will serve as a platform to share my research insights and educational content on topics that lie at the intersection of mathematics, computer science, and cryptography. I plan to write about:

Kolmogorov Complexity

Kolmogorov complexity, also known as algorithmic complexity, measures the computational resources needed to specify an object. It has profound implications for:

  • Understanding randomness and compressibility
  • Foundations of information theory
  • Connections to cryptographic security

One-way Functions

One-way functions are the fundamental building blocks of modern cryptography. These are functions that are:

  • Easy to compute in one direction
  • Computationally infeasible to invert

I’ll explore their theoretical foundations, candidates, and implications for cryptographic constructions.

Post-Quantum Cryptography

With quantum computers on the horizon, we need to understand:

  • How quantum algorithms threaten current cryptographic systems
  • What makes certain cryptographic schemes quantum-resistant
  • The NIST post-quantum standardization process

Block Ciphers and Symmetric Cryptography

Building on my IEEE publication, I’ll discuss:

  • Block cipher design principles
  • Security analysis techniques
  • Post-quantum considerations for symmetric cryptography

Stay Tuned

I’ll be posting regularly on these topics, combining rigorous mathematical treatment with accessible explanations. Whether you’re a fellow researcher, a student, or simply curious about cryptography, I hope you’ll find something valuable here.

Feel free to reach out if you have questions or topics you’d like me to cover!

entry.title: Introduction to Kolmogorov Complexity
entry.content:
What is Kolmogorov Complexity?

Kolmogorov complexity, independently discovered by Ray Solomonoff (1960), Andrey Kolmogorov (1965), and Gregory Chaitin (1966), provides a mathematical framework for measuring the “complexity” or “randomness” of individual objects.

Intuitive Definition

The Kolmogorov complexity of a string \(x\), denoted \(K(x)\), is the length of the shortest program that outputs \(x\) on a universal Turing machine.

\[K(x) = \min_{p: U(p) = x} |p|\]
where \(U\) is a universal Turing machine and $$ p \(denotes the length of program\)p$$.

Simple Example

Consider these two strings of length 1000:

  1. 000000...0 (1000 zeros)
  2. 4c1j5b2p0cv4w1x8rx2y39umgw5q85s7... (random characters)

The first string has low Kolmogorov complexity because we can describe it simply as “print ‘0’ 1000 times”. The second string (if truly random) likely has high Kolmogorov complexity, close to its length, as there’s no shorter way to describe it than writing it out.

Why Does This Matter for Cryptography?

Kolmogorov complexity has deep connections to cryptography:

Incompressibility and Randomness

A string is Kolmogorov random if its complexity is close to its length:

\[K(x) \geq |x| - c\]

for some small constant \(c\). Cryptographic keys should ideally be Kolmogorov random, meaning they cannot be compressed or predicted.

One-way Functions

The existence of one-way functions is closely related to complexity-theoretic assumptions. If \(P \neq NP\), certain functions are easy to compute but hard to invert, which is the essence of one-way functions.

Pseudorandomness

A pseudorandom generator produces output that is computationally indistinguishable from random. Kolmogorov complexity helps formalize what “random-looking” means.

Key Properties

Invariance Theorem

The choice of universal Turing machine only affects Kolmogorov complexity by an additive constant:

\[|K_U(x) - K_V(x)| \leq c_{U,V}\]

This means the complexity measure is robust up to a constant.

Uncomputability

Theorem: Kolmogorov complexity is not computable.

This is proven by a diagonal argument similar to the halting problem. If we could compute \(K(x)\), we could create a program that generates a string with complexity greater than its own length, leading to a contradiction.

Coming Up Next

In future posts, I’ll explore:

  • Connections between Kolmogorov complexity and Shannon entropy
  • Applications to cryptographic security proofs
  • The relationship with one-way functions

Stay tuned for more on this fascinating topic!

Further Reading

  • Li, M., & Vitányi, P. (2008). An Introduction to Kolmogorov Complexity and Its Applications
  • Kolmogorov, A. N. (1965). “Three approaches to the quantitative definition of information”

entry.title: One-way Functions - The Foundation of Cryptography

link.title: One-way Functions - The Foundation of Cryptography

entry.content:
What Are One-way Functions?

One-way functions are the cornerstone of modern cryptography. Informally, a one-way function is a function that is:

  1. Easy to compute: Given input \(x\), we can efficiently compute \(f(x)\)
  2. Hard to invert: Given \(y = f(x)\), it is computationally infeasible to find any \(x'\) such that \(f(x') = y\)

Formal Definition

A function \(f: \{0,1\}^* \rightarrow \{0,1\}^*\) is one-way if:

  1. There exists a polynomial-time algorithm \(M\) such that \(M(x) = f(x)\) for all \(x\)
  2. For every probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm \(A\), there exists a negligible function \(\text{negl}\) such that:
\[\Pr[f(A(f(x))) = f(x)] \leq \text{negl}(n)\]

where the probability is over the random choice of \(x \leftarrow \{0,1\}^n\) and the randomness of \(A\).

Candidate One-way Functions

Integer Factorization

The RSA assumption relies on the difficulty of factoring the product of two large primes:

  • Easy direction: Given primes \(p\) and \(q\), compute \(n = p \times q\)
  • Hard direction: Given \(n\), find \(p\) and \(q\)

Discrete Logarithm

Given a group \(G\) with generator \(g\):

  • Easy direction: Given \(x\), compute \(g^x\)
  • Hard direction: Given \(y = g^x\), find \(x\)

Hash Functions

Cryptographic hash functions like SHA-256 are designed to be one-way:

  • Easy direction: Compute \(H(m)\) for any message \(m\)
  • Hard direction: Find \(m\) given \(H(m)\)

Why Do We Care?

One-way functions are necessary and sufficient for many cryptographic primitives:

Necessary For

  • Pseudorandom generators
  • Digital signatures
  • Commitment schemes
  • Secure computation

What They Enable

One-way Functions
       │
       ├── Pseudorandom Generators
       │        │
       │        └── Stream Ciphers
       │
       ├── Pseudorandom Functions
       │        │
       │        └── Message Authentication Codes
       │
       └── Collision-resistant Hash Functions
                │
                └── Digital Signatures

The Big Open Question

Do one-way functions exist?

This is one of the most important open problems in cryptography and complexity theory. We know:

  • If \(P = NP\), then one-way functions do not exist
  • If one-way functions exist, then \(P \neq NP\)

However, the converse is not known: \(P \neq NP\) does not immediately imply one-way functions exist.

Post-Quantum Considerations

Many candidate one-way functions (like integer factorization and discrete log) can be broken by quantum computers using Shor’s algorithm. This motivates the search for post-quantum one-way functions based on:

  • Lattice problems: Learning with Errors (LWE), Shortest Vector Problem (SVP)
  • Code-based problems: Syndrome decoding
  • Hash-based constructions: Based on one-wayness of hash functions
  • Multivariate polynomials: Solving systems of multivariate equations

Connection to Kolmogorov Complexity

There’s a deep connection between one-way functions and Kolmogorov complexity. If one-way functions exist, then there are strings that are “pseudorandom” - they look random (high Kolmogorov complexity) but actually have low complexity because they can be generated by a short seed.

Summary

One-way functions are:

  • The foundation of modern cryptography
  • Believed to exist but not proven
  • Related to fundamental complexity questions
  • Threatened by quantum computers (for some candidates)

In the next post, I’ll dive deeper into specific one-way function candidates and their security proofs.
